Bring CASH as they do not accept credit cards!  The menu also includes a variety of sandwiches and about 12 entrees from Chicken Parmesan to New York Sirloin and Ribs. I need to go back cuz I hear the hash browns are to die for and I want to order something that comes with the much renowned soup, and crudite plate. It's not a fancy place- more like a northern Wisconsin bar with limited decor and functional seating but what it lacks in ambiance is certainly made up for by the great service and food. Simple, quick, free parking lot and a little historic. All that for $32 for 2 steak dinners and 4 beers. Now that has to be the best deal in the city!!

1.description: This is a piece of Chicago history.  Great White Sox bar, although the bar tender admitted to being a Cub's fan.Good pub food.  Great prices. Stop in before a White Sox game and make a day of it.

55.description: Having been here once before for drinks, I knew what I was in for.  The history, the Sox fans, the cheap beer (cans), the fast service, and the unfrilly atmosphere.  This past week I took my N.Side dad and brother and my S.side boyfriend for dinner before the game (seems par for the course by the looks of the dining room).  No one's mentioned the food so here goes:  We sat immediately, got drinks immediately - (2 rounds of beer cans, 2 rounds of soda cans), got orders taken immediately, were served the bread basket immediately.  I'll slow down.  The bread comes wrapped in plastic - which could make you feel good that no one's paws have touched it - or wonder how old it is.  Salads and soups were next.  Then the meals.  Nothing fancy.  Nothing bad.  Sandwiches here range from $4-6 and come w/ fries and cole slaw.  The dinners come with salad or soup and range from $8-17.  Carnivores only - it's meatloaf, veal, chicken, ribs, or fish (orange rouhy or shrimp).  We had the ribs, meatloaf, veal, and chicken vesuvio.  All good - fresh meat, big portions, tasty mashed potatoes, canned green beans.  Total came to $50.  You get a little more than what you pay for in a Sox-friendly environment.  Good for groups, kids, etc.  Not for dates.  Unless you're so S.Side it hurts.

9.description: Oh how the mighty have fallen,  Sad to say, Schaller's can no longer be considered a great "dive" or neighborhood bar--it's now a trendy "dive" bar and a tourist attraction.  The beer is way overpriced--$3.50 for a 10 ounce draft--really?  Give me a break.  I used to love this place but now its full of posers and hipster wannabes. R.I.P.

26.description: Great food! Great location near us cellular field!  I will be back!

25.description: Loved it. Locals and great down to earth servers. A few baseball loving out of towers but nice guys too.  Don't go here looking for high class but a comfortable dive bar all day.

12.description: Cash only. Go in the side door. Colleagues brought me here for lunch, and I will definitely come back for more warm, affordable, delicious food and regular beer.

21.description: Schaller's is a down home favorite originally owned by the Schaller family which is still owned by them to this day.  Their staff is almost all family and it shows.  The care they put into everything they do just makes this place great.Their ribs are one of the best you will ever have.  Their London Broil is amazing.  I wish they would perminently add their stuffed pork chop to the menu because it is something out of this world.If you get a chance, go to this age old speak easy from back in the day.  It is special.  You can see the history of the building right in the walls that survived the Chicago fire.  Very cool that a place like this still exists.Thanks for keeping it original!

17.description: The #6 registered alcohol license in Chicago along with prohibition history.  Friendly service & great turkey club.

10.description: I love the cubs and I live in the Far North Side - Andersonville. But I love coming to this bar and watching some sox baseball with my sox fan friends. Brings me back to another time. One of the best spots in the city and another great reason to check out one of Chicago's great neighborhoods - Bridgeport.

5.description: It's the oldest standing bar in chicago so definitely worth checking out just for that, aside from that there's not that much special about it, not to say it's bad, they sometimes have live music, the beer is cheap, though just standard domestic selection, i know their food is supposed to be good, i haven't had it yet, but it's a full dinner menu, one of these days i'll come back and try it

3.description: First things first- this place is LOUD. It has really high ceilings, so everything is amplified, & it just so happens the Sox played the Cubs today, so everyone is out full force, which means I have to shout for my dining companion to hear me- kind of stinks, but whatevs. It is a bar, after all.We came for the corned beef & cabbage, raved about in other reviews... but not on the menu. I asked about it & was told they have it "sometimes." Bummer. Went with the other review standout: butt steak, while my other half settled for the corned beef sandwich. The sandwich was dry & flavorless but the steak was good. I asked for a Blue Moon & the server had no clue, so if you're one of those that's only into craft beers, it's not the spot for you.Service was good. The much aged owner was sitting in the dining area, & everyone would stop to say hello to him as their passed. From his cap I gleaned he's a WWII veteran- awesome. Overall, it was an ok experience. I live in the neighborhood, so I'll probably be back, but I'm not in a rush.

35.description: We walked in on a Sunday night to an older crowd and old interiors. I felt I was transported back in time to prohibition, with windowless walls and an old bar. We ordered Cold beet - very coldMacaroni salad - goodSalad - very good garlic dressingPrime rib - ok but with generous portions.Rib and steak combo - ok good ribs but small portions.I thought the price was decent for good portions. I have to come back the chicken wings, since they were voted as best by toc.

19.description: Schaller's is a down home favorite originally owned by the Schaller family which is still owned by them to this day.  Their staff is almost all family and it shows.  The care they put into everything they do just makes this place great.Their ribs are one of the best you will ever have.  Their London Broil is amazing.  I wish they would perminently add their stuffed pork chop to the menu because it is something out of this world.If you get a chance, go to this age old speak easy from back in the day.  It is special.  You can see the history of the building right in the walls that survived the Chicago fire.  Very cool that a place like this still exists.Thanks for keeping it original!

28.description: Shaller's has been in operation since 1881, which is some trick since prohibition lasted for 14 years.  The grandson of the original owner still runs the place and lives upstairs.  These facts alone get it four starts.  Shaller's is like stepping back in time, but not to the 1880s, but more like the 1950s.  There is a large calendar provided by the 11th Ward Democratic Committee and a picture of the first Mayor Daley proudly hanging behind the bar.  You get the feeling that over a million parking tickets have been fixed behind these walls and if you met the right person in there you can become an alderman and give patronage streets and sanitation jobs to your friends.  It's a bit of an old time machine politics museum.  The lunch crowd consists of blue collar men who don't mind having a little beer while taking a breather from the jackhammer.  As an advocate of drinking during lunch I think this adds to the atmosphere.  There is only cheap domestic beer on tap and probably about 15 bottles of liquor behind the bar.  The service is a good as I've ever experienced and the food is better than your average bar fare.  Don't wear a Cub cap.

45.description: I wasn't disappointed but I wasn't impressed either. The food was neither very tasty nor bland. The mashed potatoes were on the runny side and the liver was thin and livery. I finished all of my food and was satisfied. The price wasn't bad. $15 for two w/out drinks. The rolls wrapped in cellophane threw me off.If I eat at home or at a cheap bar, this is what I'd expect.

33.description: I've been here several times before a Sox game for some lunch/dinner/beers. Food- great. CHEAP. French dip- mmmmm, BBQ Beef sandwich- very tasty, grilled cheese- makes me happy. Sandwiches are about $6 and come with sole slaw and fries. There are also dinners that are about $15 (steaks etc) that come with soup/ salad/ side. I've never had one, but they looked great as they came by. Drink- $3 drafts and old style cans. Love it!! Nothing like an Old Style in a solo cup to get you in the mood for the game. Service- always have a fun time with the waitresses. Very easy going. Get you in and out in plenty of time for the game. Atmosphere- this is the seller. I love the southside dive bar feel as opposed to my usual northside stuffy overpriced bars. The people here are so fun- employees and customers. Everyone is friendly and there for a good time. Apparently the place was a speakeasy back in the day, and the waitresses will tell you some "stories" if you really want to hear them. Nothing fancy here, just good food and friendly people. ETC- go in the side door! and CASH ONLY!

43.description: ::Shrug::Went here for lunch with Jonathan A. I never really get to the southside for anything so I was excited to check this place out. According to some other yelpers Schaller's Pump opened in 1881. I wish it still had that classic vibe and looked like it was that old. When we walked in there was a decent about of people at the bar eating corned beef and cabbage and drinking cans of old style. The corned beef looked good and I thought for a moment about trying the liver and onions but in the end I ordered a fried ham sandwich. It wasn't anything special just a BLT with ham, but only cost $5.If you grew up here and hung out here a lot I could see it being a good time especially when there is a Sox game going on. But in the end its just a bar that serves home cooked food rather than your typical bar food of fries and wings.

2.description: A Chicago staple. This place is old school, no frills. Best spot before a Sox game. Order yourself a corned beef sandwich and a beer and pat yourself on the back because you're at one of the greatest spots on the south side. You may see Mr. Schaller being adorable and enjoying his dinner. Always puts a smile on my face.PS anyone that gives this place a bad review is a yuppie that shouldn't have left the north side. If you can't appreciate a place like this, I don't know what to tell ya.

18.description: Four of us went here before the Sox-Giants day game.  It was all we expected and more.  The place was packed, but the service was still fast and friendly.  We had heard great things about the corned beef and cabbage and the butt steaks but two of us chose the prime rib lunch (prime rib for $10 - can't beat that), and two chose the sirloin tips over noodles.  Both were excellent.  Be sure to ask for horseradish to accompany your prime rib.  We had pitches of MGD and Lite, which was just what we wanted and was a great fit with our lunch choices.We verified that we could leave one of the cars in their lot for the game, and took the other to the park.  It was our great privilege and distinct honor to give Mr. Schaller, the owner, a ride to the ball park.  93 years old, WW II vet, and still going strong.  It's the Schaller family that makes this the great place that it still is today.

41.description: The staff members were welcoming enough, but this place felt very dated.  Both the decor and the people were old.  Very, very old.Until I'm pensionable, I won't stop back for a beer.

52.description: Schaller's. I was taken to this place when i was a baby, and grew up knowing this was the oldest restaurant in Chicago. Jack Schaller, grandson of the original owner, still runs the place, and he's more than happy to let you leave your car in his lot while you walk over to the Sox game. The waitresses there are family, too, and they've been serving there since I was legally able to drink. The cook, not family, has been there for almost 20 years and plays music there some nights. And as others have pointed out, Schaller's is steeped in Chicago democratic politics. Daley's brother is there practically every day. The front door (that's not in use) is probably the nicest part of the building. It got installed when a drunk driver drove into the building off of 37th. Everything else is pretty old and utilitarian.If you like corn beef- get it here. All their food is great and consistent and pretty south side Irish. I mean, it's not some gourmet shit, but it's the best you can get for an awesome historical old man bar nestled in still semi-blue collar Bridgeport.Expect to drink cheap beer out of cans, but you really wouldn't want to drink swank beer in a place like this.A great place to watch Sox games, but if it's a crosstown series don't expect to get in- you need reservations a year in advance. Yes, for high profile Pale Hose games, you need reservations.

50.description: Schaller' Pump, such a great bar located in Bridgeport. I believe it is either one of the oldest or the oldest bar in the city. The atmosphere here is completely friendly, as the service is on point. I have been here a few times before a Sox game, and the food and drinks have always been good. They even allow you to leave your car in the lot if you order dinner before the game, not bad! I recommend the BBQ ribs served with hashed browns...sounds a bit weird, but it is a fantastic combo!

4.description: What a little gemOldest continuous liquor license in the city of ChicagoHomemade from scratch foodSpecials are delicious regular food is delicious The staff are friendly multi generation family ownedHighly recommend not fancy but you feel like you're at somebody's homeThere's an ATM they only take cash and the prices reflect that -very reasonable

6.description: So we saw a list of 25 classic Chicago restaurants and we were down that way anyway and decided to stop in. I'm sure it's different in baseball season, but this place is sad. It's not like the Green Mill or even the California Clipper that has an older look to it, this place is just run down... with a drop ceiling.The beers are weak, nothing special. We split a butt steak with hash browns and it was meh. There's a back room past the bathrooms and I think someone was smoking back there because it reeked. I know it's cold outside, but seriously? It's just tacky.Bartender was really friendly, but I wouldn't come back here.

22.description: Went back and figured it out - I had ordered the wrong thing.  Their fried chicken is a thing of beauty!

15.description: Great dive bar with an amazing corn beef sandwich! Love that it has been around forever and the owner who is 90 lives above the bar! :)

57.description: Here's another of one of Bridgeport's institutions, conveniently located across the street from the Democratic Ward office. If only those walls could talk! Do you want to hear what's going on in the neighborhood, or what's on the mind of the average south-sider? This is the place to come find out. Schaller's has a decent menu of pub-type grub. This is a great place to watch a Sox game if you don't have a ticket.

20.description: oldest bar in chicago...had a prime butt and an old style before catching a flight out of town...check another off my bucket list bars to visit.

36.description: An experience. Miller Lite in cans and a bunch of regular-types growing roots out the bottom of their barstools. The corned beef sandwich was fine. The Dem Ward office is across the street. Must be an amazing place to watch a Sox game.

14.description: Filled with locals from the Bridgeport neighborhood, pictures of the first Mayor Daley and 11th ward Dem organization paraphernalia, Schaller's Pump is a great dive bar with lots of character.  Don't come here expecting a long beer list and gourmet food. I got the fried ham and hash browns, and both were delicious. It's a bit of a walk from the field, but you can't beat the parking deal. When paying your tab, just ask the waitress for a sign for your car, and there's no extra charge.

3.description: As good as it gets in the Chicago area.If you like Cajun food, you will enjoy this.Well worth the money.

1.description: A bit pricey doesn't begin to explain it! $10 for either one of the sandwich selections. Here's the catch...that $10 does not cover anything extra to make your sandwich a meal. No drink, no fries, no sides, nothing. I chose the Cajun Shrimp Po Boy. The sandwich was good it came with plenty of shrimp & garlic inspired seasoning but unfortunately I can't say that it was $10 good. I told the staff that I was looking for something that offered a real Cajun kick. I was in the mood for spicy food & I didn't receive that at all. I also tired the gumbo. I'm a sucker for a good hot soup. This gumbo ticked me off. Yes it was flavorful but there was 1 too many missteps for it to cost $12! 1. I have a nagging feeling that the sausage that was used in this gumbo was the Aldi brand polish sausage. 2. Gumbo is one of those dishes best served with a dash of love. I should NOT be spitting out pieces of crab shells & fish bones.3. $12 & I can't get a couple of crackers or some cornbread? SOMETHING?!?!I gave 2 stars b/c despite the hang ups the food wasn't terrible. It was definitely an experience I could've passed on though. Someone needs to rethink this business model to get me to try this spot again.

0.description: I had the Cajun Connoisseur cater a Mardi Gras party this past weekend.  We had the shrimp jambalaya with andouille sausage, garlic chicken, and vegetarian red beans and rice.  The food was excellent.  The jambalaya had lots of shrimp and sausage and had a nice kick to it.  The red beans and rice had plenty of flavor without any meat.  The garlic chicken was nice and garlicky.  We had more than enough food for about 50 people with those three full trays of food.The service was also excellent.  Kyle and Regina were very friendly and thorough with confirming my order.  They delivered on time and they accepted credit cards.Thank you Kyle and Regina for helping to make our Mardi Gras party a success with your excellent food!

2.description: Had the Cajun style king crab po boy on Italian bread, with spinach and tomatoes . A bit pricey for a lunch meal, but was filling. I got it Cajun style, next time would try with the garlic style. Everyone should try their food atleast once. Seafood is fresh and you get a good amount of it for the price you pay. Ran into someone eating gumbo from here and they said it was delicious, so will definitely try that next tine. Owner took my order and was really nice as well and recommended this dish. Will be back!

5.description: I got the gumbo soup and it was cold

6.description: Absolutely delish. Staff/Owner is friendly too!

7.description: I love the food on this truck.  The cajun po boy sandwiches are amazing.  The gumbo is delightful and definitely tickles your tastebuds.  I've also had the scampi (garlic) salad and loved it.  The portions are a good size for me.  I visit whenever I see them.  The one thing I haven't tried are the shrimp (or lobster) and grits and I can't way to do so.  I promise you that on many of the extremely frigid days in Chicago, this food will warm you.  Can't say enough good things about the food, owner and staff.  GOOD STUFF!!

8.description: I wish Yelp had negative star ratings.  I really wanted to like this food truck simply because the owner has a winning personality.  He had me convinced he had the "BEST Gumbo in the STATE!".  I had a sample of the shrimp  and grits and they spectacular. So why wouldn't the gumbo be equally as impress.  So, I gave up  $12 (Twelve) for the half bowl gumbo.  The gumbo was dismal  to say the least. It was nothing more than brown water with flickering of rice, shrimp and CORN.  The dish was lacking the traditional  "Gumbo" smell, texture and taste.  Total Disappointment!

9.description: I tried this truck for the first time waaaaay back in September and have since made it my mission to work my way through the menu.  I am a fan of flavorful, spicy food and The Cajun Connoisseur has delivered that with every meal. So far I have had the Gumbo, the Baked Potato with Cajun Style shrimp, several variations of the Po Boys they offer (try it with cheese!), and my new favorite the Shrimp and Grits.  The quality of ingredients and size of their sandwiches has been consistent on every visit.  I have never had an "off" or "bad" meal from this truck and I regularly recommend them to friends.  If you are looking for a hot, filling meal full of great Cajun flavor this is the truck to visit.

10.description: This food truck is super over priced and not very good. I got the shrimp po boy. It was extremely garlicky, basically just tasted like garlic and shrimp. Didn't have any Cajun flavor at all. The shrimp was very rubbery. He accidentally gave me fries that I didn't order, and then tried to ask me to pay for the fries. I would give it one star because it was so bad that I ended up taking two bites and throwing it away, but it wasn't inedible. It just wasn't very good and I would never eat here again. A waste of money.

4.description: Guy at the truck was nice. Gave me a sample of lobster mac n' cheese which was tasty. I ordered the king crab po' boy. Lots of good flavors going on. And lots of real crab. It is pretty heavy on the butter, but(ter) that's why I couldn't stop.

3.description: Great selection of merchandise but way, way overpriced (think "ballpark" pricing). Still it's a great way to kill a few minutes before or after the game. They do have a couple pretty cool items and some of the memorabilia is great to look at and reminisce (2005 World Series Champs, I love you).

1.description: There's no home games at the U.S. Cellular Stadium in the month of June.  However, daddy J. wanted to snap a couple of photos in front of main entrance.  After our photo-capturing mission was accomplished, we noticed the Chicago Sports Depot was open for business (1200 to 1700 hour daily).  The entire store was extremely spacious, with two (2)-floor worth of merchandise for customers to browse.  If you're a Yelp check-in avid, Yelp check-in has a 10% off offer on the entire purchase.  I wouldn't mind getting some of the Chicago Bulls t-shirt and White Sox retro caps, if I've had an unlimited budget.  Licensed merchandise is often expensive.  On the other hand, sales associates were friendly and greeting us immediately upon entering.  Speaking of the entry, I assumed that there would be no entry allowed from the W. 35th., St. during the non-game days.  The sign guided us to the entry at the parking on the back.  That store would be much more fun to hang around if White Sox were playing.

2.description: The Chicago Sports Depot is the NEW team store for the Chicago White Sox! The Store also carries merchandise for ALL Chicago sports teams, even the cubs.This store opened on 11/19 to much fanfare, and it was easy to see why. TWO MASSIVE FLOORS of sports gear, with an obvious heavy dose of the White Sox. Prices were decent considering this store is attached to the home of the White Sox, and there was an excellent variety of offerings ranging from baby pacifiers to $500 autographed bats.Free parking is available on non-game days(but why would you come to the store on a game day unless you were going to the game?), and it's easily accessible for those that rely on public transportation(CTA #24, #35 and #39 busses stop nearby, and the CTA Red line Sox/35th station is a block away. The Metra station on 35th is 2 blocks away). Some of the cool features here are the custom t-shirt shop(sox designs for now), and the permament home of the 2005 World Series Trophy, as well as the cool murals of the Chicago Sports teams that have won a championship in the last 30 years(so no cubs..haha).HIGHLY RECOMMENDED for any Chicago Sports fans to check out!

5.description: The space is beautiful and huge, but the selection is less than Grandstand (right down the block), and the prices are typical for a MLB ballpark (outrageous).If you're arriving via red line on a non-game day, don't bother trying to use the main entrance on 35th Street.  It's locked.  I guess they figure anybody who can afford their prices must be arriving via limo.

6.description: If you are a White Sox fan this is the place to go. Grandstand down the street is great and I agree the prices are more reasonable there. The selection of the Big Ten teams, other Chicago teams and items you might not find anywhere else is great. I would even call it is a destination place to shop. Definitely a very cool store. My six year old who is not a big sports fan yet was mesmerized by the place. Definitely check out the murals by the elevator of the Chicago Championship teams.

7.description: Maurice must be smoking the crack pipe because the prices were not ball park prices AND they had a bigger selection of stuff than grand stand (not counting all the garbage grand stand sells). If you are looking for a run of the mill generic stuff - go to grand stand. For custom jerseys and autographed stuff go to the depot. They also said that the inventory is going to rotate every 4 months. (I am guessing all the old stuff will be sent to grand stand)

8.description: It's a beautiful store but as far as merchandise goes, Grandstand on 35th and Wallace is the place to go for Chicago sports gear. Plus, the folks at Grandstand are really nice and very helpful.

0.description: I stopped in a couple of days ago to pick up some White Sox gear. Namely a Chris Sale authentic road jersey (which unknown to me was an impossible task).  After Doug (I'm pretty sure that's his name, he had glasses) heard of my plight, he immediately found out what he could do for me.Even though Grandstand was the 1st choice, they couldn't do anything custom for the road jersey on the spot.  However, Doug guaranteed me that he could get me my custom jersey in 45 minutes.  Doug was the ultimate professional that day, probably the best service I've ever had in a retail setting.Unfortunately this is why they're rated 4 stars instead of 5, I couldn't get the jersey made.  They were out of the letter S.  A little more than a week out from Opening Day & the letter S was out of stock.  Regardless their stock of White Sox gear is vast.  Name it, they'll have it.  Except the letter S.

4.description: I checked this place out yesterday after the game and visually it is stunning.  The displays are nice, the merchandise is laid out well, and the TV walls are amazing.  The selection includes not only Sox gear but Cubs (?!), Hawks, Bulls and even a lot of Big 10 stuff (that's actually pretty smart).And great as it all looks, and it's beautiful, the shock comes when you see the price tags.  I get that even a replica jersey is going to set you back a hundred or more but there was an "aged" sweatshirt that immediately caught my eye which I would have walked out with... except that it cost $70.  For a sweatshirt.  Made in India.  Some of the cooler t-shirts were up around $40-$50.  Those are rock concert prices.Granted, gear inside the park isn't cheap either but if you're going to go for mass appeal and even be open on off days...  I'm not sure who can afford this.  I can, but I just couldn't bring myself to drop that much dough on something like a t-shirt, cool as it was.

1.description: Only reason they are even getting 1 star, is because the service was decent, and I think you have to give a star in order to be able to rate on Yelp.  There are 2 people that answer the phones, and only one of them actually knows what he is talking about.We purchased flowers for our wedding 1 month ago, peonies and baby's breath, and the peonies were garbage.  We were only able to use a handful of the peonies for our centerpieces because the rest were either dead, or had not even opened up yet.  When we called back to receive reimbursement for only half of the cost of the peonies, we were almost blamed rather than sympathized with.  The guy there said that clearly we were not florists.  The owner got involved and asked us to provide pictures, which we did, and apparently that wasn't enough because his "decision stands" to not reimburse us.We do not recommend that anyone get flowers here unless you are ordering something like baby's breath or a simple rose, and you have a plan B for the day of your big event.

2.description: I purchased flowers for a large event I hosted at a hall.  They have great quality flowers and excellent service!

0.description: I know nothing about flowers. So going into this wholesaler with a few photos of what I was going for, I was super scared. The guys here showed me examples of what they recommended and gave me a few pointers. I left feeling really anxious about how it would all turn out; after all, these were for my WEDDING.I had friends assemble them into arrangements after picking them up the day before the wedding, and they were beautiful. For $140 I got all of my wedding flowers. We had so many compliments about how great they looked. Fresh, affordable and professional.

58.description: It's a great place to go during a Sox game. This place use to be Puffer's, but the bar was sold back in October 2006. There are bowling and golf machines and darts can help pass the time as you go through the menu of more than 35 varieties of beer, with an ever-changing tap-beer selection that includes new specialty brands on a VERY frequent basis. A selection of fine wine is also available.

56.description: Nice bar, I definitely plan on coming back here the next time I head to a Sox game. My friends and I were able to sit in the outside patio area with our pitchers of beer and chill. Disappointed that the bags weren't out though.

29.description: Went here before a game. Has a great selection of beers. Bummer that there is no food, but love the options of the drinks avaliable.

42.description: Good selection of beer and reasonable prices.  This bar seems to have a wide range of patrons, which can make just about anyone comfortable in this place.  The bar can get a little crowded during baseball season but most of the time, it is just busy enough not to be annoying (i.e. you won't be getting elbowed left and right).

23.description: Like many have commented, this is a decent neighborhood sports bar. Friendly/talkative bartenders and patrons. One of the few go-to spots after Sox games. It's pretty laid-back here. Tons of parking (during non-game days of course). Nothing special but also not awful.

47.description: if i could give negative stars this place would be like at a negative ten.....me and my buddy stopped in here after having dinner nearby and we were just being our silly selves and my friend decides to breakdance randomly to the Pharcyde......dancing is better than acting like a lout, starting fights orobnoxiously flirting with every woman in the bar, right? WRONG! A thick necked bouncer told us to leave......lesson learned is this : Act like a prick, a thug, a lout...ur good to go.....harmless dancing= being an Al-Qaeda Operative.....i cant tell you how sad it makes me when truly innocent fun is banned from places that have suresly seen worse judging by the patrons inside and outside smoking...avoid like the plague

8.description: A cool place for the locals. Affordable prices, decent food, and Bridgeporter's that make for good comic relief, who have some interesting neighborhood stories to share. If you're in the neighborhood for a game, this is a solid dive-like option. The also have a jukebox, patio, darts and bags!

31.description: If this place has anything going for it, it's that it's very clean.  Amazingly so for a bar.The downsides are three, but I feel that they are important enough to warrant comment here:(1) the staff and patrons did not seem to be very friendly toward this neighborhood outsider;(2) if you need to take a dump, there is no stall around the throne in the men's room and no way to lock the handle on the main door; and(3) the beer they had on offer was kind of expensive.

34.description: Solid bar.  Nice people there.

16.description: $7.50 for a pitcher of PBR. Really cant go wrong with that.I went with my brother to redeem a groupon I had bought. The bartender comped us the difference of the groupon and our purchases(3 pitchers of ribbon), so that was cool. He got a nice tip as a thank you.Digital jukebox, darts, and a punching bag game are the entertainment. Also, plenty of tvs(that were tuned to the hawks game and the late bulls game). I suspect I'll hit this place up come Sox season.

13.description: Be still, my heart.Why, you ask?+2.50 PBR drafts.  Yes, drafts.  +For the beer fans - huge beer list+Darts!+Plenty of room to sit at the bar+Lovely song selection jukebox+NBA on one screen, NHL on the other+Friendly bartenders+Diverse crowd!  Won't see that on the Northside+Can bring outside food in!  Saw people order a pizza and bring in Chinese food.  +Staff was nice enough to provide plates and utensils!+Parking galore+Revelations reached (finally!)It's safe to say that I love this place.  I can't wait for my return visit!

11.description: I haven't reviewed mitchell's? I'm surprised....This is definitely a neighborhood Bridgeport bar....the natives can sniff out the yuppies from the north side....Cheap Drinks....Jukebox and tables....It's a dive bar with personality and a decent beer selection.It's definitely a cheers of that neighborhood.

39.description: i give this place 5 stars in my head because i was here when the sox won the world series (it was still puffers).. and i will never forget it,possibly one of the best nights of my life. i've been back here after the name change and i really dislike the place. its filled with the locals, old and young.. i don't mind the older ones but the young ones with their bridgeport attitudes need to stay home, i don't believe half of them are even old enough to drink.

37.description: Sarah makes one of the very best margaritas I have ever tasted in my life.  It is also quite efficient in its buzzability.  The patio is a good space except for the porta-potties, although I guess they might come in handy if the place was crowded.The tvs are too loud when there isn't a game on -- otherwise a good place to meet friends and drink a margarita if Sarah is working.

0.description: You can smoke on the patio which makes it perfect for me. Decent crowdGood sound system for watching games Food is okay

38.description: Formerly the location of Puffer's Tap, it is a fun place to go. The place does not have the same ambiance but it is still a good place to go. Go Sox!

51.description: If you want to get a taste, a real taste of BRIDGEPORT. than come to mitchells.soo im just saying coming here is what finding out what bridgeport is all aboutex)beer=bearthree=treethere=derethem=demits the real chicago!psDONT NOT WEAR YOUR CUBS GEAR HERE!!!! word to the wise

27.description: Be still, my heart.Why, you ask?+2.50 PBR drafts.  Yes, drafts.  +For the beer fans - huge beer list+Darts!+Plenty of room to sit at the bar+Lovely song selection jukebox+NBA on one screen, NHL on the other+Friendly bartenders+Diverse crowd!  Won't see that on the Northside+Can bring outside food in!  Saw people order a pizza and bring in Chinese food.  +Staff was nice enough to provide plates and utensils!+Parking galore+Revelations reached (finally!)It's safe to say that I love this place.  I can't wait for my return visit!

32.description: Great beer garden? Check!Amazing beer menu? Check!Best White Sox bar? Check!

54.description: GREAT White Sox bar!Before games, you can get a whole pitcher of PBR for the same price as one beer in the ball park ($6).  Fun clientele and lots to do.  There's darts, Golden Tee and the outdoor patio is great.  One reviewer said he was disappointed that the bags weren't out, but I'm sure you have to ask for them!  You need to leave your license as collateral and they'll let you use the bags set as long as you want. Before games the bar isn't too crowded and after games it's packed with fans.  There's great TVs and a juke box.  On Opening Day they even have pitcher specials and an outdoor grill serving free hotdogs and burgers.  I'm pretty sure they don't have food normally, but I've never asked.  They have some snacks like chips and peanuts available for purchase.I lived in the area when this used to be Puffers and I think this was a change for the better.  Puffer's was fun, but a bit too much of a dive for most people's taste.  When it changed to Mitchell's, a lot more IIT students started coming over on weeknights and it made for a fun atmosphere (I'm obviously a college student).  On any given night, there's always a good crowd, but it's not too crowded; a great bar for games and any night you're in the neighborhood.

48.description: They have good beers. It's a decent place before and after Sox games. But any other time this place is awful. All the snobby neighborhood kids hang out here. So if you don't want to hang out with the Gotti boys on Friday night as they shove stacks of singles into the touchtunes jukebox and play the entire lil wayne album, don't go here. It was better when it was puffer's.

44.description: Funny the "little gems" you come across when you put your mind to finding a new place to relax and have a drink. While a bit unfamiliar with Bridgeport (no that's an understatement- I had NEVER been here before) someone had suggested Mitchell's to me as a great place to grab a beer and some friendly conversation. So on a snowy night- we headed south down Halsted to Mitchell's. The first thing I loved? Plenty of street parking right in front of the place. We settled in at the bar and glanced around. Mitchell's, while not huge, has room for at least 20 at the bar and tables scattered around which will seat at least 30 more. If just siting and drinking is not your thing- they have a variety of bar games including my favorite "bar darts". They also have a pretty good jukebox although how good it is depends on who is shoving the dollars into it on the night you are there (heavy metal anyone?) The beer is cheap, the selection of beer fairly impressive, and the people friendly and chatty. On the first time we were there- the bartender won our hearts (could it have been the free shots?) and it is because of her that we have been back several times. I also discovered "wooden nickels" at this place as they were used as markers for free drinks. And who doesn't love a free drink? Not fancy- which is just fine with me. I am so over those places that want to be like Mitchell's and try so hard but never achieve it cuz its the people that make a place like this. And you can't get that everywhere!

24.description: Decent place. went there on sat before the sox game to watch the first bulls playoff game. had 4 or 5 TVs, though as we sat at the table it was not necessarily a good line of site to see any of the TVs. you kind of had to turn your head away from the group you were sitting with to see the game. good beer selection though

7.description: Ok, my score maybe a little bias because I know many of the bartenders there. But really, this is a nice place to go and they have a large selections of beers. The place was Puffers before becoming Mitchell's, which the new owner have done a great job.They now offer food. So stop in and have a cold one while munching on some decent bar food.

49.description: Great place to go for a Sox game.  The crowd is engergetic and no frills.  The PBR pitchers are $6.75, you can't go wrong.  But if you want a beer with a little more flavor they have a large bottle selection.

40.description: Another gem of a place in the south side.You do realize that Chicago is a "working class" town founded on steel and constructions....not the service and food industry?!?!If you do, then you'll appreciate the bars that exist in the southside as original and authentic..........now what do I mean by authentic?  Well you can walk into many a bar in the north and not one...........and I mean not one person will speak to you, but on the south side everyone is quick with a word or joke and makes anyone feel at ease and "one of the crowd."Mitchells is very much like this...the neighborhood is very safe (cop station just down a block or so) and the bar was recently renovated, so it is clean and well lit.Add several TVs and bar darts and you have a little place to have some drinks and some fun.  No food though, but they do have an extensive menu delivery list.Beer is very reasonably priced and a good selection in addition to some specials though the week.  The crowd really picks up the later you get into the night.A gem in a sea of gems actually........whether you believe it or not.

53.description: Mitchell's Tap is a great bar wether your looking for a spot to catch the game or just a place to have a few drinks after work.  The have a very good selection about Domestic and Import beers on tap and in bottles.  The back patio is great on summer nights.  The clientel is a mix of young 20 and locals that could be their parents age, which I think is one aspect that makes this place as good as it is.

30.description: Im a cubs fan (gasp!) and I actually enjoyed this place. Came here last night and amists the sox jerseys, sox hats, sox anything that you can prove your a south-sider.. there was great music and cheap drinks. Crowd was 21-28 ish and literally 75% male - which of course I didn't complain!

46.description: This place is totally hot.  Yeah, I said it.Although I wasn't here when it was late nor packed, the staff and the large beer selection gave a great vibe.  The bartenders were super friendly and chatty and it seemed like everyone was just waiting for the clock to hit a certain time to really start to get bumpin'.  Some dude was practically doing a little tap dance for me. There's one of those TouchTunes jukeboxes here so the music is a wild array of whatever someone poked at.  BEST 'wooden nickle'.  If you know what that is and know that you want one, then just a tip - they have them here so be nice and maybe you'll see one.I passed by again later that night and half the place seemed to be wearing Mitchell's own brand of apparel.  It's safe to say they have a following.

1.description: Popped in with some friends after the White Sox game on Sunday afternoon. Was surprised to see just a handful of (probably) regulars at the bar. Menus are on the tables, but you have to place your food order at the bar. If you want drink refills, same thing -- no table service.Italian beef and fries are pretty good, but you can get good to great Italian beef and fries 100 different places in Chicago. I liked that it was laidback, and the staff seemed friendly enough.

55.description: i don't know much about mitchell's but what i do know is while consuming cheap pitchers of pbr i got to listen to marla, the bartender, sing along with italian frank sinatra numbers.  honestly, i have no idea what she was singing but it put me in a good mood and made me want to keep on drinking.  it seems like a great happy hour spot.

9.description: This bar has good days and bad days because it is REAL. I hate to sound like a cliche, but it is not OBSESSED with the latest mico brew dejour.  I just order my Coors Light, without a sneer. I like it. Always attracks a couple jerks, but this is a REAL BAR. It isn't phony or try to be some pseudo working class bar that you might find in other neighborhoods. Just a bar....but I like it....Also, you can walk out the door and literally step on the bus practically.

26.description: Just an average bar on an average Chicago street. The only thing that makes this place unique is that it is a White Sox bar actually in the white Sox park neighborhood. Aside from that this is just another of the same looking corporate/store front bar. It has some good diverse beer choices and a nice beer garden when it is warm. Aside from that you will find the same sports loud mouths and their jersey's that you will find in Wriglyville, only that they are wearing different colors.

25.description: This place is actually awesome.  And I eat ALL the pizza when I go.

12.description: MITCHELL's TAP NOW HAS FOOD !!  Bartenders are cool/great. Food is yumm! Try the Tuscan pizza. Basil so fragrant I wanted to dab it behind my ears!! Thursday night is now Live Music. Usually trios... can't fit much else and not sure if patio is open or not but when it is, there is a port-a-potty outside lol Yeah Mitchell's!!!

21.description: Mitchell's is a solid bar to catch your favorite team--especially if your team is the SOX. Pretty great prices on some top-notch local beers, both on tap and bottles. Mitchell's also has darts and a punching/show how macho you are/sprain your wrist game.

17.description: Just scored this place yesterday before the Sox game. Real nice place to add as a craft beer destination in Bridgeport. I will review again at another time to be completely honest with a rating as opening day at the Cell surely affected the service level. I must admit that once served the staff was very accommodating.

10.description: The best neighborhood bar to go to everyone is a local and everyone knows someone I love this place great bar, great bartenders. And the drinks are cheap and delicious every time good food menu. Jason makes the best Vegas bombs ever no other bar can come close. Ask him for one and thank me later!

5.description: Gray place to hang out with old friends and make new ones with the locals.Clean bar and tablesDarts a few video gameCute back porch Friendly bartender and staffLive singer...she was cute and performed well.

3.description: The tap is like my second home! My favorite bar in the neighborhood!  Love the patio, people and beer! Jimmy is the best!!

35.description: I managed to visit here on a Sunday evening when the north side b**eball team was on the ESPN national telecast. However, Mitchell's is an egalitarian and tolerant bar. The north side fans were clustered on the west edge of the bar, closest to the venue's largest flat-screen TV (subscribed to Comcast cable). The south side fans (whose club had lost that afternoon), were closer to the door. I seated myself in between, but closer to the south side fans.I began coming to this address when it was "Puffers' Bar". From what I overheard, after the south side club won something colossal in 2005, the Puffers drew an offer from some other wanna-be bar owner. They felt this was the time to go out, and so they sold. But aside from whoever is the new owner, the venue has not greatly changed.You can obtain a quality beer here, typically an import, but Three Floyds can be found here, as can Point (which is what I ordered), and it has two Samuel Adams beers, including the seasonal on tap.It took a while for Mitchell's to warm up to me. I was generally ignoring the TV, and reading an English-language pamphlet I brought back from Japan. I did not attribute this to xenophobia. The peculiar combination of what was on TV, and what had occurred earlier that day is to what I attribute it.But just the same, I can't give Mitchell's more than three stars for now. In succeeding trips to the south side, when I cycle back through Mitchell's, then I'll ponder if it can go higher.Transit options: The #8 Halsted route is how to get the 'last mile'. It runs northbound [to Orange & Blue Line "L"s] until 1:00 am and southbound until 2:10 am. The #44 Wallace-Racine route is two blocks east of Halsted, but it ceases running at 11:35 pm on weeknights, and after 6:00 pm on weekends. The #35 35th Street route halts operation at 1:00 am.

19.description: Funny the "little gems" you come across when you put your mind to finding a new place to relax and have a drink. While a bit unfamiliar with Bridgeport (no that's an understatement- I had NEVER been here before) someone had suggested Mitchell's to me as a great place to grab a beer and some friendly conversation. So on a snowy night- we headed south down Halsted to Mitchell's. The first thing I loved? Plenty of street parking right in front of the place. We settled in at the bar and glanced around. Mitchell's, while not huge, has room for at least 20 at the bar and tables scattered around which will seat at least 30 more. If just siting and drinking is not your thing- they have a variety of bar games including my favorite "bar darts". They also have a pretty good jukebox although how good it is depends on who is shoving the dollars into it on the night you are there (heavy metal anyone?) The beer is cheap, the selection of beer fairly impressive, and the people friendly and chatty. On the first time we were there- the bartender won our hearts (could it have been the free shots?) and it is because of her that we have been back several times. I also discovered "wooden nickels" at this place as they were used as markers for free drinks. And who doesn't love a free drink? Not fancy- which is just fine with me. I am so over those places that want to be like Mitchell's and try so hard but never achieve it cuz its the people that make a place like this. And you can't get that everywhere!

28.description: Oh Mitchell's, how do I love thee? You're our new go-to place after Sox games. You welcome my motley crew in every time, and you even have a punching bag game to get all my frustrations out after I get off work. Only downfall is that sometimes I can't find a place to park my car after the games. Non-game days, parking is a breeze. See you next season!

45.description: I was really surprised by this place.  I went out tonight expecting to stop here first, with Bernice's being the main event (due to all the good things I'd been hearing about it), but Mitchell's came out ahead.  We had extremely friendly bar staff (male and female, so I don't suspect a gender bias) hooking up free shots and drinks from the moment we entered the door.  I'm not sure if it was because we were obviously new, or if they were just in a good mood, but it was appreciated.  Aside from it being free, the selection of beers was also respectable.  I was happy to see, first on the list, Three Floyds Alpha King, my current favorite brew.  Also present was Fin du Monde, delirium tremens, the increasingly-ever-present fat tire (on tap), and about 20+ other beers of various styles (import and domestic/swill and good).  Ample room to be there with a group of friends without having to feel packed in like sardines at a divey bar, yet it still felt pretty homey and low-key.  The only thing that would have made it better would have been a pool or air hockey table, but apparently (according to one of the regs) Daley drove those out of southside bars because they were causing trouble (the pool tables at least).To make things better, the jukebox selection was great, and kept me busy for quite a while, when I wasn't busy in conversation with the really friendly regs and staff.  I will definitely be coming back here again, especially if I'm in the mood for a messy night!

33.description: The more I go here the more I dig it.

43.description: They guy who said this place deserves negative stars is absolutely correct in my opinion.  This place was so much better when it was Puffer's.  They used to have this one bartender who would drink during his shift and forget to charge for drinks, plus people never got out of line because you knew there was no security and you would have to settle it by yourself. Ah, those were the good ol' days.  Now it looks like a place out of Orland Park.  Listen up people just because it has belgian beers doesn't make it alright. Plus the crowd is now all the guidos from either armour park or I'm guessing somewhere from Burbank perhaps.  I had to go here one time to meet some people before a ball game and they put my scotch and beer in plastic glasses.  Not cool. not good better off going to bernice's or catcher's

2.description: They built bathrooms outside in the yard. Bathrooms that lock. So now a guy can take a crap without someone walking in on his big ol' swinging dick. The employees are great and the food rocks. Now that I can take an uninterrupted dump, I give you 5 stars and would recommend Mitchells to anyone looking for a place to go for a few drinks and/or good food!

18.description: Another gem of a place in the south side.You do realize that Chicago is a "working class" town founded on steel and constructions....not the service and food industry?!?!If you do, then you'll appreciate the bars that exist in the southside as original and authentic..........now what do I mean by authentic?  Well you can walk into many a bar in the north and not one...........and I mean not one person will speak to you, but on the south side everyone is quick with a word or joke and makes anyone feel at ease and "one of the crowd."Mitchells is very much like this...the neighborhood is very safe (cop station just down a block or so) and the bar was recently renovated, so it is clean and well lit.Add several TVs and bar darts and you have a little place to have some drinks and some fun.  No food though, but they do have an extensive menu delivery list.Beer is very reasonably priced and a good selection in addition to some specials though the week.  The crowd really picks up the later you get into the night.A gem in a sea of gems actually........whether you believe it or not.

41.description: This is a pretty good place, and was really the only option for the year that I lived a few blocks away. The is cheap, but they have nicer options if that's your thing. There's a plastic dart board, and in the summer you can play bags on the back patio. The atmosphere is really relaxed and the bar is rarely crowded unless there's a Sox game. On the day of the home-opener they have a giant party and free food. It's totally packed and everyone is friendly. I've met some questionable sorts here, but you just have to careful about who you hang out with and you'll be golden

52.description: This place was my first stop in Chicago and I must say a taste of Bridgeport is at Mitchells. The folks were awesome, the booze was served in good portions. I did meet some local that asked we buy a delirium before we leave, the barkeep looked at me and decided i was worthy of it. ..... I dont remember walking home, but i do remember throwing up Connies delicious pizza.

50.description: LOVE LOVE LOVE this bar. Bar staff and patrons are very friendly. Come during a Sox game and you will love it. I have only gone after a Sox game but you want to make sure you get here earlier than later. It can get pretty packed. Bathrooms are nice too and will have to wait in line if its crowded. Outside patio area in the bag is pretty large. Music is good when played just a little loud for my taste but if that's the only negative thing then eh, whatever. No food at this bar just and FYI but you can order and have it delivered or just go down the street and get some awesome Mexican food at 35th.

4.description: I came here to watch the wildcard game between the Steelers and the Ravens, and this place wasn't what I was expecting. This is a tiny, neighborhood dive bar in Bridgeport, and it was hopping on Saturday night. Way busier than I expected. This is also the kind of bar you expect to hear grunge in, not pop music headlined by four Taylor Swift songs. The princes are on point, and the specials can be a great deal. My only gripe is that many of the TVs are small and hard to see, especially the ones high up. Not every table has a great view. So this is definitely a fun place to watch a game, but if you are very invested and want a high quality viewing experience, I would definitely look elsewhere.

6.description: This isn't a destination for people outside of Bridgeport, but it is a good option when you're in the neighborhood. Most of the crowd drinks Miller Lite, but there is a very good selection of domestic craft beers in bottles. The specials are nice & cheap too.

22.description: I've been going to Mitchell's for years, and at one point (though I hate to admit it) I was going a few too many times a week. It's a great neighborhood bar that has really cleaned itself up from way back when. Very decent prices and it's a great place to play darts (if you get there early enough). The bartending can be bad at times, but this is usually only when it's really busy and thus you can't squeeze up to a spot at the bar. The beer garden is a nice bonus and I would love to go play some bags right now...

15.description: Not a bad place. Good food, good drink specials, nice place to watch a game or throw some bags

57.description: Oh, how I long for the old days of Puffer's.  Mitchells' Tap, I have a love/hate relationship with you.In October 2006 the place was sold and has undergone many changes.  While I appreciate the upgrade is TVs, and the great re-bricked patio, I can do without many of the new clientele.  I long for the days of knowing what to expect when I meander across the street and belly up to the bar.  These days I can be seen peeping in the window to see who is inside before I make the trek to a barstool.Recently, there has been an influx of young, rich Italians taking over.  I get tired of $150 Juicy Sweatpants (because, like, this place isn't cool enough to, like, really get dressed and ready), Chanel handbags, and 90's dance music (Sexual by Amber makes me want to rip my ears off.) blaring from the God-awful downloading jukebox.Despite the sometime awful people who choose to consume their devil-juice at Mitchell's, the place does have some great highlights.They have a great beer selection.  German's and Belgians being what strike my fancy.  They have a great, albeit slow, bartender on Tuesdays and Thursdays who fights the for Jazz on the Jukebox.  They have a great, large beer garden.  They are in excellent proximity to my home.  I simply must play real-life frogger to get home at 2am.So, visit Mitchell's, just peek in the window first!

20.description: Mitchell's gained an extra star for its excellent craft beer menu. If it weren't for that, I would completely avoid it. The bartenders, while nice, don't have a clue what's going on. One bartender who seemingly gets his fashion tips from someone on the Jersey Shore was EXTREMELY adamant that Bell's (Oberon) wasn't a craft beer. This was because we caught a mistake in him overcharging us on a craft beer special, so he obviously was too prideful to admit he was wrong. Interestingly enough, even their beer menu classified Bell's as a craft beer. So forget getting any help from the bartenders and be sure to do the math yourself. This bar also transforms into the Jersey Shore (minus the women, sorry guys) after 9PM. Complete with tight shirts, an overwhelming stench of Axe colonge, and even a punching machine. I wouldn't mind it but since the bar isn't that large, the sound that the punching bag makes it extremely annoying after, say, the 50th use in 3 minutes. I grew up on the southside and even I tend to avoid these people. If you are planning to visit Mitchell's, get there early to avoid the night crowd and take whatever the bartenders say with a grain of salt, or, go right down the street to Bernice's. If you're craving the craft beer scene, go a extra few blocks to Maria's.

36.description: Down by Negative Addison street, the demographics on this part of South Halsted are similar to its north side counterparts- 2/3 male, concentrated at 25-35, the only diversity marked by the direction of your baseball cap.  The difference is, on this side of Madison, things are just as chill as they ain't on the other side.Hockey, like the south side, is an underdog.  Mitchell's tap is a good place to experience both underdogs in one visit.  Five televisions (one large screen), sound booming in surround, and absolutely everyone there is glued to the television (at least on a Blackhawks playoff night).  Being a hockey idiot, I hoped to learn a thing or two by eavesdropping on my neighbors' commentary.  Wisdom was delivered in single-line packages:"put the goddamn stick on the goddamn puck you a**hole!""f*** the ref!""move the f'n puck!""between his f'n legs!  that's a b*tch!" (Detroit 1-0)There are no fewer than 40 beers offered here, some of them real fancy (Delirium Tremens, Fin du Monde) alongside some real cheap options (PBR $2.25, most domestics at $3.25).  Prices are carefully calibrated, usually something-twenty-five or something-seventy-five."THAT'S HOW YOU DO IT, BABY!" (Chicago 1, Detroit 1)Footage of the Hawks' goal replays repeatedly.  One guy, like a pirate with short term memory loss, hoarsely screams "YEAH!" each time Kane's high shot sinks into the exact same spot at the back of the net.  Nothing new happens, the game drifts into overtime.  Cherry bombs are selling like hotcakes.  On second thought, I've never seen people get so excited over hotcakes."Somebody hit the m'f'ers!""Shoot the f'n puck!"Who says men aren't in touch with their emotions?Early overtime, the Wings score their second goal.  Sobering as it is to see the Blackhawks' turnaround season crash to a halt, everybody's still buzzed.

14.description: I have been to Mitchell's many times and will go back again, but only when I can sit outside.  My experiences can be summed up in four statements:Great beerLovely gardenNo dogs in the gardenAngry vibe(seriously, every time I have been in there I feel like a fight is about to break out...)

3.description: This a little hole-in-the-wall pharmacy, but it's nice alternative to pharmacies that jack up prices like crazy. I was able to get my prescription filled for half the cost that Walgreens charged me. It must be why they are so busy for such a small place. Ron, a guy behind the counter, helped me to check if my insurance covered the cost of my medicines, and since it didn't, they offered me a reasonable price. I will recommend for people in the neighborhood.

1.description: What a fantastic experience! The staff is unbelievable ( Can you imagine being greeted by name and offered assistance throughout a pharmacy!?! )  Another reason I took the time to write this review is because I have saved SO much money switching from CVS to Voss Pharmacy and wanted to express my gratitude! Thanks Voss Pharmacy :)

2.description: Been coming here for years and it's the best that it gets. Neighborhood business with a friendly staff. Lowest prices of any other pharmacy chain in the neighborhood by far. Highly recommended

0.description: Simple family pharmacy with a bodega inside. Cash and cards accepted. They take all kinds of prescriptions and most forms of insurance. They're friendly, and super fast- most of the time can have a prescription ready within ten minutes or less. This is the kind of stuff I've come to expect in Bridgeport, with less chain stores than other hoods I've lived in before. Will stay loyal to Voss for years to come.

3.description: Cue the Katy Perry music... "I wanna see your peacock...."Birds of a feather flock together in wine and paint.A beautiful concoction of GNO, fine wine, paint, and laughter equals a fantabulous night! I highly recommend Wet Paint Chicago because I had the most wonderful experience with my best girlfriends. I never knew I would be able to create such a cool piece of art and drink wine at the same time.It was a bit tricky finding the location because it is inside the Bridgeport Art Gallery. You can find parking in back then you go up to the 4th floor and through the gallery into a room where blank canvases are set up for your class!I recommend arriving early so you can reserve your seats.Our class' theme was to draw a peacock. The instructor was very helpful and informative and kept assuring us that no matter how our peacock turned out it is art and it is beautiful!Me and my girlfriends were shocked that we all made unique yet pretty peacocks after all the 5 bottles of wine we consumed. After the 5th bottle, the instructor suggested nicely that we get a private party. Haha but we were not offended because we knew we were getting a bit chatttttty.Again, I can't stress enough about how much fun me and my girls had. They usually have deals on groupon, youswoop, and even yelp - so check them out!Whether you're looking for a great unique time out with your friends or trying to find the inner-artist in you ...... I definitely recommend Wet Paint Chicago.As Vincent van Gogh once said, "Paintings have a life of their own that derives from the painter's soul".

1.description: This was My first time going to byob painting class with wine on 01/10/15.....the hostess and instructors were wonderful and attentive. I went with a group of almost 20 ladies...my only wish is we could have gotten a discount or groupon deal. They provide wine glasses, ice, and cork openers. There is plenty of party with elevator access to the 4th floor.

2.description: I found out about Wet Paint Chicago through Groupon.  You register online ahead of time & pick which painting you are interested in (we planned about a month ahead because classes fill up fast).  My girlfriends and I signed up for the Peacock painting.  Finding the studio was a bit tricky, but luckily they answered the phone right away and met us at the door.The room has long tables and are set up with canvases, stands, brushes.. the works.  This class is BYOB so come prepared with your favorite drinks- the ladies next to us brought snacks so there's an idea for next time!  In the back there is a small bar provided with wine glasses and openers.  Each seat has a good view of the instructor.  It was nice that the helpers replenished our water during class and offered to bring us more paint.  They played upbeat music which was enjoyable.  Overall, a great experience & we were all happy with our paintings!

9.description: I have been to Wet Paint Chicago several times....  The Society Lounge (BYOB Establishment) is where the night begins and ends.  The atmosphere is very relaxing and comfortable.  There you can socialize while having a drink or two...The Class/Painting area is roomy and well lit. You are provided with an endless supply of paint along with the tools needed to paint a complete picture with the help of Teaching Artist.The Artists/Teachers are wonderful.  Because I was there several times I experienced all of the artist and their styles. They are very patient and easy to follow each and every time I was there...  With their guidance I was able to paint a picture that I was proud of.  I walked in a person and walked out an Artist!Last but not least the Owners... Both Merry and Emily are very friendly and go out of their way to make your experience a memorable one... So if you are looking to do something different I highly recommend Wet Paint Chicago is the place to go.

10.description: I love this place! The location is so comfortable. The staff is super friendly and the artists teaching the classes are very talented. I've been here two times so far and cannot wait to go back. It is BYOB and they offer glasses and/or ice. They are very helpful. Great for a Girls' Night Out!

4.description: I went here to celebrate my birthday. This BYOB painting is becoming more and more popular. I liked the fact that I could have a private area for just my family and friends. Everything is done through their website. The actual studio is kind of hard  to find though.

6.description: Had a great time at this place. Instructor was nice and went rather slowly so everyone could do a good job with their painting.  BYOB is awesome (wine glasses are provided), the hostess provided snacks while we were waiting for class to start.  The location is in the Bridgeport Art Center which is really nice. I will be bringing friends here!

12.description: The class was packed. In the end it was fun. The reason I only state 'ok' is because the instructor was rushing through the painting. Everyone was still on drawing with a pencil and she was like ok done with the pencil let's paint. Then she got so into her painting she just stopped talking by the end. So, pretty much my friend and I just did our own thing and the painting ended up coming out descent. When we first walked in no one really greeted us it was kind of just come in and find a spot. Which is find I don't mind the casual atmosphere. The girls that were running the class were drinking beers and walking in and out while we were painting to talk to people outside of the room. The class was extremely hot so make sure to wear lighter clothing or you may pass out. All in all I would do it again just probably somewhere else.

5.description: At first I wasn't loving it, but by the end it was fun.The place is hard to find. I'd never been to the Bridgeport Art Center before and took 10 minutes to find Wet Paint's location once I was there, and another 5 to 10 to find my way out at the end of the night.I arrived at 6:50 for the 7 p.m. class. No one greeted me, no one told me what to do when I got there. Some other class attendants were already drinking the wine they brought. So I sat down and did the same. At 7:15 the instructor finally showed up and told everyone we'd be starting in 15 minutes. So basically I sat there for 40 minutes. Maybe if I was meeting up with people, that time would be good for catching up. But I guess I felt like I could've drank and talked at home or at a restaurant just the same.I was looking for more of a laid back vibe and instead people were shouting at each other and carrying on. Maybe I just wasn't drinking enough. The instructor, Patty, was helpful and I think with her help I actually painted something I like. I don't consider myself artistic and almost failed 6th grade art, so this is a big deal. Now that I know what to expect, I think I might go on a weekend with friends as something fun to do.

13.description: I have only been to wet paint once but I cannot wait to go back again. The staff is fun and friendly and the location is really cool. At first I wasn't sure what to expect since I haven't picked up a paint brush since grade school but the instructors did such a great job I left with a painting that is now hanging on my living room wall! I was delighted when my friends said they didn't believe that it was actually my painting and not something I bought. But honestly I have to give all the credit to the instructors who take you step by step through the process and I guarantee you will end up surprised with your own talents. Wet paint is a great place to go if you are looking to do something different, fun, and creative. Also, wet paint is a great deal: the canvas and paint are included and it's BYOB. They have lots of great paintings to choose from on their website and are open to suggestions. I am excited to go back to paint Monet's Sunset in Venice. Wet paint was a great experience and a lot of fun!wetpaintchicago.com

11.description: I got a deal on Groupon and went with a group of friends.  It was so much fun, Merry and Emily were extremely nice and welcoming.  There was awesome music playing while we painted.  It's BYOB, so we enjoyed ourselves! I painted once before in high school for an art class but I barely  remember any techniques I learned.  The instructor made it very easy to learn.  Everyone in our class had great results! I'm DEFINITELY going back here again.... more than likely to throw a party with my friends.

8.description: Great place and good atmosphere. It's byob and you walk out with your own mini masterpiece. I was there when rachel was teaching and took my two sisters and they're paintings looked pretty good.

0.description: My boyfriend and I went to Wet Paint last night to paint the "Colorful Tree" painting. We had so much fun!I didn't know what to expect since I had never been to a BYOB painting class before. Once we arrived, we were told to sit in the bar area and enjoy our drinks and snacks. The class started at 7pm, but you don't start painting until 7:30 (the first half hour is for drinking, mingling, and getting settled in). I was nervous to paint since I'm not much of a drawer, but the instructor and owners are extremely helpful. We had a blast! The instructor lets you work at your own pace and allows time to help students if needed. It was nice to be able to paint without feeling rushed. Around 9:30, the formal class transitions to an end, and the last half hour is for finishing touches, finishing drinks, and cleaning up the work station.Be forewarned that this place can be tricky to find. It's inside the Bridgeport Art Center on the 4th floor. The parking lot is directly behind it (north). You enter where it says "Bridgeport Art Center" in the back, and walk up the stairs to the fourth floor. Go down the hallway and turn right. You may think you stumbled into an art gallery... but in the back corner you'll see all the canvases set up for the class.Tricky to get to, but well worth the time! It was an awesome date night and we would definitely go back.

7.description: My boyfriend and I went for my birthday. We had a great time (especially the byob part!) We did have a hard time finding this place then had to call to tell them we were at the door (a bit scary) Once we got inside, we fell in love with the art gallery which held their classroom within. Our class had 2 other couples in it which was nice and relaxing. It did seem like it was our instructors first day on the job, she didn't verbally communicate well. But other instructors wee there to help which was great. My boyfriend and I will be back, this time for an extreme-beginners class!

1.description: Just stopped in to the new Treasure Box Consignment Shop on Morgan Street - lots of great clothes, accessories and jewelry, and the owner is amazingly friendly and nice!  I'm really excited we have a shop like this in Bridgeport!  Plan to shop there a lot!

2.description: This was my second time at the Treasure Box on Morgan Street.  This is great for the neighborhood.  Its not a thrift store, but a resale/consighment shop. Most of the clothes are priced reasonable, found a couple that still had tags on them.  The owner could be a little more friendly.  On this occasion I thought she could of organized the shoe.  They looked like where ever she put them down thats where they are.  Just five minutes of organizing would make the shoes more appealable.  I will go back and again I am glad to see this in the neighborhood.

0.description: A nice addition to Morgan St., a well stocked good sized consignment shop. Everything from children's to some plus sized items. Casual to evening wear. Some shoes, boots and purses.Everything is in very good condition, no junk and many new items. I've been to plenty of consignment shops that the clothing is tattered or has a stain that can't come out, I didn't see stuff like that here.Everything is reasonably priced, meaning it's not Goodwill, don't expect to find a shirt for  .50 cents, but I did see many that started in the 10$ range.Worth a stop in.

29.description: I came here for take out a couple of times. It was recommended by the locals. I ordered the orange chicken and it is very delicious. Very fast service. I totally want to go back. The mango smoothie is totally delish!

42.description: The best to me love the chicken egg foo yung and beef fried rice

23.description: Good food, good prices, very friendly and courteous staff.  I visit here at least once or twice a week

47.description: This is my favorite Chinese place in the neighborhood! The food is always yummy and hot. The veggies (especially the broccoli) always looks fresh. My personal faves are the Orange Chicken and Kung Bao Chicken. You can order via phone or online for pickup or delivery. When you order via phone for pickup, they usually tell you 10-15 minutes which is awesome because I am usually starving! The place is nothing special to look at on the inside, the there is ample seating if you want a casual dinner.

8.description: I love this restaurant. Me & my fiancé order from here a few times a month. We live about 10 mins from the restaurant, I'm sure more with traffic & they always deliver to us in a timely manner. Our order is always correct & freshly hot.

31.description: I've been going to this place since they've opened. The people there are so nice! The food is great was never disappointed. and delivery was quick and friendly. I would recommend it to all my friends!!!

34.description: We LOVE Happiness!  It's only a couple of blocks from our house and it's affordable.  The food is as good as any Chinese American Food I have ever eaten in Chinatown an dthe prices are better.  When we dine in ...the place is clean and the service is good.  Thanks Happiness for making us Happy!

16.description: Favorite neighborhood place.  Really enjoy the egg rolls and my new favorite "Scallops, Shrimp, and Mushroom Combo.  Lots of sea food and very tasty.

13.description: First time I actually sat down to eat here and I found a screw in my shrimp fried rice! That's right a rusty screw!!!!!!! Last time I'll EVER eat there.

11.description: New to the area. A block away from my place. Love it! Really good, staff is nice. All the food has really good flavor and tastes freshly made. Definitely recommend.updated review- i ordered the smoothy with tapioca and the tapioca was hard. sent it back twice and the third time, i just gave up. gross! 4 starts to two. what a fail.

39.description: I loved this place for years, spent literally $70.00 here a month ordering delivery. The last few times I ordered, it seems they can't make up their mind on additional charges. I usually order a dish with extra meat. I always got charged $3.00. Today a woman tells me its $9.00. Really $9 additional on a $6.00 dish? When I questioned that, she basically tried to say I was a liar. This is after I gave her my number and she pulled up my address. Pretty sure you could see I'm a regular... I have receipts here where I'm always charged between 3-4 bucks additional. Now they want to be rude and try to come across like I'm trying to pull a fast one? When I asked her to confirm the charges, she huffed and hung up on me. There are WAY to many good chinese restaurants in Chicago to have to put up with someone talking down to you & acting like that. Maybe they do well and don't need to treat their customers respectfully, who knows. All I know is I will never spend another penny here.

37.description: I question some of the people who wrote these previous negative reviews. One reviewer is complaining that the restaurant gave way too much food. Since when has that ever been a bad thing that a restaurant gives good portions? That same reviewer also complained that the place could use a good scrubbing. It just got renovated!!! I've been in there and the place looks clean; has this person ever been to a restaurant in Chinatown!? This person seriously has no idea what she's talking about and has no credibility. On to the food. This place seriously has the best crab rangoon I've ever had. The ma-pa-tofu was tasty and the orange chicken was amazing. This place has tasty food, gives large portions and is affordable. What more can you honestly ask for?

0.description: I've been going here for awhile for lunch and thinking about it for monday. You can't beat this place.
